title: Big Brother Australia reboot sends fans into meltdown as it's announced the show will return in 2020
text:
It was revealed on Thursday that Big Brother Australia is set to return to screens on Channel Seven in 2020.

And within hours of the news being announced, fans took to social media to share their excitement that the show would be coming back - five years after it last aired.

One fan gushed: 'I can’t believe Big Brother is actually coming back! Holy s**t actually want to cry and go crazy... I’m still in denial.'

It's back! Big Brother Australia will air on Channel Seven next year, according to TV Blackbox. Pictured: Big Brother 2014 contestants Aisha Mckinnon, Lisa Clark and Skye Wheatley

'Y'all big brother Australia is coming back next year and i’m so excited,' another fan wrote, while a third added: 'Big Brother Australia is coming back! Oh how I've missed it! 5 years was way too long!'

And it appears the show won't be short of applications - as dozens revealed they had already sent in theirs in the hopes of starring in the fly-on-the-wall show next year.

'Just applied for Big Brother Australia 2020 hope I can be a part of it #BigBrotherAU #bigbrother2020,' another fan gushed.

History: Big Brother, which was filmed at the Dreamworld amusement park on the Gold Coast, premiered in 2001 and lasted for eight seasons on Channel 10. The show later aired between 2012 and 2014 on Nine, with Sonia Kruger as host. Pictured: Sonia and housemate Tim Dormer

'I'm so excited!' Fans in their masses headed online to share their excitement at the show's reboot, which was announced on Thursday

Another chimed in: 'Also f**k it, i’m gonna apply for big brother, wonky mutilated nips saggy old man skin & all, sorry not sorry fam #BBAU.'

Big Brother, which was filmed at the Dreamworld amusement park on the Gold Coast, premiered in 2001 and last aired in 2014 on Channel 10.

TV Blackbox reported that Seven had purchased rights to the format, after Channels Nine and 10 reportedly rejected offers from production company Endemol Shine.

Channel 10 turned down the opportunity to air Big Brother because chief content officer Beverley McGarvey is 'not a fan of the show'.

Obsessed! Many fans revealed they were already sending in their applications for the popular fly-on-the-wall show

Long time coming: Before securing a deal with Seven, Endemol Shine had been pitching the show to several Australian networks. Pictured: Big Brother logo during the Channel Nine years

Nine decided against it because the network already has a 'strong slate' planned for 2020, including season seven of Married At First Sight.

According to TV Blackbox, Channel Seven plans to finance Big Brother using the budget originally allocated for Sunday Night.

Endemol's chief creative officer Peter Salmon told Deadline: 'It's rare in most big territories that there isn't a conversation about [Big Brother] in some shape or form every year.

'We're close in a couple of interesting territories to further reboot, but I don't want to get ahead of ourselves.

'There are constant conversations and exchanges of ideas where we're thinking what's next.'
description: It was revealed on Thursday that Big Brother Australia is set to return to screens on Channel Seven in 2020 - and fans have shared their excitement over the shock news.
authors: Nicole Douglas For Daily Mail Australia
